title: dad creates life size sarcophagus
story: Dad creates le-size sarcophagus to help son with school project on ancient EgyptRichard Briggss son Alexander studied the sarcophagus of Tutankhamun. His dad then Richard crafted a replica out of foamboard, polystyrene and papier-mache – all for £Engineer Richard Brigg took his son Alexanders school ancient Egypt craft project extremely seriously Image: Richard Brigg   SWNSByStephen WhiteNews Reporter:,  Apr |comments When Richard Briggs’s little boy asked him to help with the school craft project on ancient Egypt, he had a good long Sphinx about it...And created a le-size sarcophagus, with a mummied pharaoh inside. Richard, , an engineer, was volunteered for the job by seven-year-old Alexander, a Year Three pupil.They studied the sarcophagus of Tutankhamun before Richard crafted a replica out of foamboard, polystyrene and papier-mache – all for £.The model, complete with the mummied pharaoh, was a huge hit with Alexander’s classmates and his teacher. Richard, chairman of Moorside Primary School PTA in Lancaster, Lancs, said: “I have a history of making stuff for the PTA, so my boy’s teacher asked himhe thought I could build one and he came out of school one day with the message to have a chat with her.  “It was a challenge, but I thought I could give it a good go, so I went away, had a think and managed to create this.” He spent  hours painstakingly crafting his sarcophagus over five or six weeks, getting to work in the evenings after Alexander had gone to bed. Richard said: “I’m really pleased with how it all came together – it turned out better than expected. “I looked up the sarcophagus of Tutankhamun for inspiration and a few styling cues to make it at least a little historically accurate for the school rather than totally made up.“The mummied pharaoh was a leftover Halloween prop, which I bulked out with more polystyrene and pipe insulation before using papier-mache for the head.” He then dyed the mummy’s bandages with tea. He said: “It was a failure. Apart from making the whole house stink like a tea merchants, when we washed the smell of tea out, they were nearly a normal colour again.” But the sarcophagus has been a success with pupils and teachers. Richard said: “The kids were showing it off to the parents and ious classes.” Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON EducationSchoolsDaily Mirror,callToAction:ltpgtGet weekly highlights from Mirror editor Alison Phillips direct to your emaillt pgt,buttonText:,contentId:,newsletterImage:https:i-prod.mirror article.ece ALTERNATES sd _AlisonHeaderFinal.png,endpointUrl:https:response.pure interface list.php,profile:Reach_Mirror,isPureNewsLetter:true,pureMailingListId:Mirror - Alisons Newsletter,isDoubleOptIn:,newsletterSiteName:Mirror" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get weekly highlights from Mirror editor Alison Phillips direct to your emailInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: devastated family miss flight 1500
story: Devastated family miss flight for £, trip amid Manchester Airport chaosMichelle Donohue and her family missed their flight at Manchester Airport owing to long queues, despite their flight ing to the terminal because of a medical emergencyMichelle Donohue, with husband Robert and their son, missed their flight Image: Manchester Evening News WSByAntony ThrowerNews ReporterFatima Aziz:,  Apr |comments A family who missed their flight because of long queues at Manchester Airport were told they still could not get on when their plane ed to the runway because of an emergencyMichelle Donohue, , had planned a trip to Rome for her husband Robert and son, , with their flight leaving at .am. Airport chiefs admitted this week that recent disruption caused by staff shortages may last for weeks, so the family arrived four hours early but were still met by long queues, Lancashire Live reports.Despite their initial worries, they managed to get checked in - but were delayed by security where members of staff confused passengers.As a result they reached their gate at .am and, along with  other people, were told they could not board. Their hopes were later raised when their plane ed to the runway because of a medical emergency, but the captain insisted they could not join the flight.  Michelle says the chaos cost them their £, holiday - their first since the start of the pandemic. She said: It was just an absolute nightmare. “People were just in a bit of a panic and then we got to that security line and it just stopped, it seemed like hours and hours and hours. “You can see the staff are overworked and doing two or three jobs at the same time and there were some that when they were delegated one job, they were fine and they were happy and they could do it well.  “At one point, a fella was letting people through and he got told off by another member of staff to stop letting people through and he said Iaposve got loads of people trying to get out and she said Iaposve got loads of people over here. Itaposs traumatic, itaposs put me off going to that airport and I feel like this is going to be going on for a long time, itaposs not an easy fix. “One lady had come and taken a big group of us and moved us and then we stopped, and she was on her radio and then she said aposthe place I was going to move you to is closed nowapos. We were like, where do we go  My poor son was panicking.  When their plane ed they had hoped to board, but were denied, leaving them to go and find their luggage. Michelle added: They took everybody off that flight so they could deal with somebody and so we said, can we get on it now, weaposre here. “Despite it not being our fault and she said no Iaposve already spoken to the pilot and he wonapost let you on, heaposs already got his numbers.” The flight eventually took off again at around am - without the family aboard. Michelle has been able to get refunds to the activities booked in Rome but not for the missed flight yet.  A spokesman for Manchester Airport said: “We apologise to passengers whose experience at Manchester Airport in recent days has fallen short of the standard they expected. Our industry is facing challenges in scaling operations back up very quickly after the removal of Covid restrictions, which have done immense damage to our sector over the past two years. “We are actively recruiting for hundreds of new roles in areas including security, but are advising passengers that due to a shortage of staff, they may have to wait for longer than they are used to in the coming weeks, and that they should arrive at the earliest time recommended by their airline. “We understand that airlines and third-party service providers on our site are facing similar challenges and are working with them to provide the best possible experience that we can in the circumstances.” Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Manchester AirportPlanes" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news doctor-reveals-three-groups-most-"Dr Hilary Jones explains nine new symptoms of CovidByConnor LynchSam Elliott-GibbsReporter:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |comments Those with untreated asthma, COPD or an impaired immunity are most at risk of becoming sick from a Rhinovirus, a respiratory expert has stated. Medics have warned that the virus currently circulating in the community means even those who donapost have Covid- could still pose a potential health risk to others.Now a leading physician has outlined those who are most likely to fall ill. It comes as the Department of Health asked people who are experiencing the symptoms to stay home and isolate - eventhey have tested negative for Covid.The Belfast Trustaposs Dr Joe Kidney says people who become sick as a result of a rhinovirus usually see it develop in people as a common cold, BelfastLive reports. Dr Kidney said that most people who are infected with a rhinovirus only experience the symptoms of a cold, however there are certain groups who are more at risk of developing a more serious infection, such as asthmatics, those with COPD or an impaired immune system. He said that around % of the population has the virus in their nose at any one time and it is most likely to replicate in colder temperatures. Due to their changing nature it can be dficult to build a full immunity to them and it is possible to be infected by a rhinovirus within weeks of recovering from one. Dr Kidney said: I think we all get about six colds a year under normal circumstances and our bodies might have forgotten that during the lockdown.  The majority of those are rhinovirus and there are around % of us that have a rhinovirus in our nose at any one time and they like to replicate in colder temperatures such as  degrees rather than , which is our body temperature. So when it gets cold outside it replicates in our nose which is why we call them colds. Most of the symptoms are of a cold, cough, runny nose, sinusitis and they can make you feel just rotten but often not very very ill, where flu is much more likely to give you temperatures. Although you can still get aches and pains with rhinovirus as well.The issue is now we are looking at people with runny noses and we want to knowthey have coronavirus and the answer is they might do, but with a runny nose that can actually be a rhinovirus as well.Dr Kidney said that while the majority of people only experience cold like symptoms from a Rhinovirus, there are groups who are particularly at risk, with the virus being the cause of around % of asthma exacerbations.  He continued: Poorly controlled asthmatics are a real risk group and these are people who should be taking preventer treatments, a brown or red inhaler. They feel well between the episodes so they feel an the urgency to take medication because they are getting by with their relievers or blue inhalers, and then they can get very sick with a rhinovirus infection, so probably rhinovirus is responsible for % of asthma exacerbations and while it is very uncommon now, asthma deaths do occur. What I used to say is the common cold can be uncommonly dangerous to some people. The other that gets very sick are those with COPD, and an exaserpatation is the second commonest cause for people coming into hospital. Dr Kidney warned that Northern Ireland is currently seeing almost a peak number of Coronavirus cases, with Scotland recording its highest ever figure last week. However he says that the progress that has been made with treatments for virus have proven to be very effective, with NI having the lowest mortality rate of any country in the UK. He said: The great thing about the coronavirus is the vaccine, people who have been getting very very sick with coronavirus before are not now and the vaccine has been a huge success, it has been one of the greatest victories of science in this century. Our huge achievement has been the vaccine and it would be unkind of me not to mention all the drugs that have been developed during the trials, they have tremendously changed people. We had a lot of new treatments pioneered at the Mater, the Covid hospital for Belfast. Lots of patients took part and we tried about  drugs, four of which are now in use and it substantially changed how we do things. It was a real roll up your sleeves and get this job done effort and people were remarkable. It was great to see that collectively we could find the new treatments and see them rolled out right in front of our eyes, it was great to make that change. The doctor issued one last warning about the Rhinovirus saying: We have been getting them for years andyou are healthy you will get a cold butyou are susceptible it could make you sicker. People with asthma need to take their preventers, they could be between infections and they could get sick with a rhinovirus and COPD often lands people in hospital. It is best not to get themyou are vulnerable. I worry about older people taking care of young people, it can be a great spreader of these colds. title: family use bucket toilet home
story: Family use bucket as toilet in home they say is infested with fleas and ratsDemi who lives in Newham with her two daughters - including one that is disabled - has said that her current housing conditions have caused her "anxiety, depression and panic attacks" over the last three yearsDemi said the current state of the flat cause her anxiety, depression and panic attacks Image: Demi Bounaime BPM MediaByRuby GregorySamantha Mordi:,  Apr |comments A mum who says she has been forced to put her kids through the window to get into the house when it rains has lashed out at her housing provider. Demi Bounaimes, who lives in Newham, London with her two daughters - including one that is disabled - has said that her current housing conditions have caused her anxiety, depression and panic attacks over the last three years she has lived at the property managed by developers, LQ.As her housing conditions worsened, the mum-of-two says she was using a bucket as a toilet as she waited eight weeks for urgent repairs to be done when damp saw it come away from the wall.She also claims the rental property has a flea and rat infestation and has spent hundreds of pounds on pest control and cleaning products, My London reports.Demi, who is a full time carer for her eldest daughter said: LQ are awful, they donapost want to send pest control, theyaposve left us without a toilet and itaposs still flooding so we canapost leave the property. I have to move the kids through the window to get them out of the property - who puts their kids through a living room window because they canapost get through their front door  Itaposs a lot. Are you living in a housing nightmare  Email webnews@mirror to tell your storyAll my clothes and carpet was infested and I had to pay people to come out because LQ took so long sending someone out. Demi added that her children are now too scared to use the toilet in case a rat crawls up . Demi says she regularly suffers nervous breakdowns because of the reality of her housing situation, adding: I suffer panic attacks and depression due to PTSD, I feel like Iaposm suffocating in this house, thataposs how I feel. I donapost know what  to do with them, I just feel like crying. Itaposs just me on my own, fighting these scumbags but itaposs a business, theyaposre a business and they donapost care about us. She said that LQ need to be held accountable for their actions. Iaposve lost all of my pride, my confidence has gone. Iaposm always cleaning, Iaposve done my best here, I try to make it the best home for , she said.  She added: Iaposm a single parent on a low income, not once have LQ offered to reimburse us. They donapost even talk to me anymore. Itaposs got to the point where I donapost even know where I stand anymore. My kids are entitled to live in a home in  that meets English rental laws, and that theyaposre not worriedmummy has to check the bedthereaposs rats in there, ormummy has to use spray all the time - and having a space for my daughters to play outside in. After MyLondon contacted LQ, they told the publication Demiaposs toilet was fixed within four weeks, and that they are in contact with her fortnightly. Get the stories you want straight to your inbox.toone of the Mirroraposs newslettersAn LQ spokesperson said: Every resident deserves a home they feel safe and happy in, and we’re sorry that this wasn’t the case for Ms Bounaime. We’ve been working with Ms Bounaime since last year to ensure she has a home which is suitable for her and her family’s needs and have been in contact with her again this week, to update her. We’ve also committed to calling her fortnightly with an update on this process. We have visited Ms Bounaime’s home on a number of occasions over the last few years to complete ious repairs. Pest control have previously visited her home and carried out treatments, and weaposve asked them to visit her home again. An issue with the toilet cistern was reported on November , , and we attended as an emergency, however we were advised an asbestos survey would be needed before the repair could be completed. The cistern was replaced on November , . This took too long and we’re sorry for the inconvenience this caused. news uk-news five-ways-royals-keeping-prince-"Lady Louise Windsor shares memories of Prince PhilipByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Apr |commentsPrince Philipapos s death almost exactly a year ago proved to be an end of an era for the Royal Family. He had been at the Queenaposs side for  years and served for most of them as her consort - assisting her in her duties.But he also had a remarkable le of his own and was a Royal Navy hero thanks to his brave actions in the Second World War and set up the pioneering Duke of Edinburghaposs Award. He was also a patron, president and member of more than  organisations and had a passion for the natural world, engineering and technology. All of these aspects of his le were celebrated at his memorial service last month at Westminster Abbey, which was attended by nearly all members of his family.And as it approaches the first anniversary of his death aged , it seems there are several members of his family who are keen to keep his memory and legacy alive... Prince Williamaposs causes Although Prince Philip was involved in many organisations and charities over his long le, he maintained a particular interest in topics such as the environment and technology. And this approach to his work is reportedly what his grandson Prince William wants to emulate - especially when he becomes Prince of Wales, which is not a given but very likely, and eventually King. According to the Mail on Sunday, Williamaposs blueprint for doing things going forward is much the same way as the Duke of Edinburghaposs approach.Like his grandfather, William is very much interested in the environment and conservation and last year held his inaugural Earthshot Prize awards. Prince Charlesapos environmental work When it came to his views and work on conservation and preserving the environment, Philip was often seen as a pioneer. After his death, Sir David Attenborough praised his knowledge when it came to conservation and the environment.He told the BBC : He was right there at the beginning at a time when conservation didnapost mean much to many people.But he, back in the end of the s and s, when in fact the world conservation had hardly opened up... he made it a real issue, an important issue, not something to be brushed aside, not something that was a pastime but something that was centrally important.And one family member carrying on his deep interest in conservation is his son Prince Charles.Charles has often been vocal about the urgent need to save the planet from issues such as climate change and the Queen remarked last year: It is a source of great pride to me that the leading role my husband played in encouraging people to protect our fragile planet, lives on through the work of our eldest son Charles and his eldest son William. I could not be more proud of them. Lady Louise Windsoraposs carriage driving  Although his charity work and royal duties kept him busy, Philip also carved out time for one of his favourite hobbies - carriage driving. He was synonymous with carriage driving and reportedly loved nothing more than to go haring through the countryside at high speed, whip in hand, in a horse-drawn wheeled carriage.And it seems that love of carriage driving has now been passed on to his youngest granddaughter -year-old Lady Louise Windsor.In September, Louise made her public speaking debut in a series of interviews for a documentary honouring her late grandfather.And in the interviews, she talked about how she has taken up Philipaposs favourite sport of carriage driving and said: The Duke of Edinburgh has been so involved in my driving, but itaposs slightly scary as he invented the sport pretty much. But itaposs incredible to have learned first-hand from him and it definitely made us closer I think. Camilla and Sophie Wessexaposs military affiliations  Throughout his le, Philip had a close relationship with the military - and his last public engagement before his retirement in  involved the Royal Marines. He had military affiliations to many regiments and organisations and was Colonel-in-Chief of the Rles as well as Colonel-in-Chief of The Royal Electrical  Mechanical Engineers.And now these special roles have been passed on to his daughters-in-law the Duchess of Cornwall and the Countess of Wessex. Camilla took over as Colonel-in-Chief of the Rles before Philipaposs death in  - and at his memorial service last week wore her forest green regimental coat dress. Meanwhile, Sophie was announced as the new Colonel-in-Chief of The Royal Electrical  Mechanical Engineers last week. Prince Edwardaposs Duke of Edinburghaposs award role One of Philipaposs lasting legacies is the Duke of Edinburghaposs award, which helps young people to develop skills for le and work. It began in  and millions of young people around the world have taken part in the programme. Before his death, Philipaposs youngest son Prince Edward started taking on more responsibility relating to the award. And according to the Royal Family website, he is now taken over many responsibilities from his father. news uk-news kinder-recalls-more-products-including-"Gross moment shopper finds maggots inside a Ferrero RocherByLevi WinchesterMoney ReporterLiam Buckler:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |commentsKinder has issued an urgent warning after recalling more chocolate products - including Mini Eggs - over fears of salmonella.Ferrero, who make Kinder chocolate, first took precautionary measures to recall Kinder Surprise eggs over the weekend - but now the list has been extended.The Food Standards Agency has said the recall of Kinder Surprise eggs has been extended to more products - including Kinder Mini Eggs and Kinder Egg Hunt Kits. Kinder Schokobons have been taken off the shelve over fears that they might be contaminated with Salmonella. So far,  people have become ill with salmonella, with a huge number of cases being kids aged five or younger.  Confirming the recall of the Kinder products, the Food Standard Agency said: This is in connection with a potential link to a salmonella outbreak. A number of these cases have been young children. It added: To reduce the risk of any further illness, consumers should not eat the products listed in the recall alert and they the parent or s of children should follow the risk advice within it. The products affected are g eggs and three-pack of eggs with best before dates up until October , .  A further recall has been added for g Kinder Surprise eggs, including all dates from April ,  up to and including August , . Kinder Mini Eggs with a pack size of g, Kinder Egg Hunt Kit with a size of g and Kinder Schokobons that are g are also included - again, with including all dates from April  until August . Chocolate manufacturer Ferrero says it has recalled the products as a “precautionary measure” and advised people not to eat them. Anyone who has bought products with those use-by dates can contact the Ferrero consumer careline on consumers.uk@ferrero or    to obtain a full refund. title: martin lewis shares clever ways
story: Martin Lewis shares clever ways to keep warm at home without turning on heatingMoney Saving Expert Martin Lewis has provided a list of key ways that people can keep warm at home at low cost so people dont need to put on the heating after the energy price hikeMartin Lewis has come up with a list of ways to keep warm without putting the heating on Image: mirrorByRachel PughTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Apr |comments Money Saving Expert Martin Lewis has issued a clever list of cheap ways that people can remain warm at home without putting the heating on.Millions of people in the UK have been left worried about the huge hike in energy costs that has left some going cold as they canapost afford to put on the heating.But Martin has come up with a list of ways to stay warm without resorting to putting on central heating, reported the Manchester Evening News.In a change from his normal advice about cutting costs, he has been forced to suggest more desperate methods. The Good Morning Britain expert pointed out how people can wear heated USB gloves, hand warmers, an electric gilet or an electric blanket to get warm without having to heat the entire house.  His guide also told of the benefits of layered clothing and thermal tops while eating food regularly keeps people warmer. Martin said: I felt sad asking my team to put this together, but my email bag is full of folk so desperate they canapost put the heat on, I wanted to try some help. Pls share. Full cost of living survival guide coming soon Martin added on his site: This is a guide I really wish we needn’t be publishing. The reason I asked Sarah and the team to put this together is due to my overflowing e-mail bag of desperation from people who can’t afford their energy bills. So don’t see this as an ‘MSE or Martin says you should do this’. Itaposs more that we’re trying to help provide some options and information for those that may need to drastically cut down on energy usage due to financial desperation and some help for others who may want to do it out of a commitment to green issues.  Martin pointed out in his guide that it costs only £ to buy a cheap electric blanket which in turn, costs p an hour to run, even in todayaposs climate of rising costs. That equals a cost per week of £.used for seven hours a day. An electric gilet, basically a heated jacket, would cost £ to buy and just p per week to run, while USB gloves would cost p per week to run and just £ to buy. Another consumer expert Jack Monroe reached out to Martin Lewis for the guide, adding: Thank you for your vital and heart breaking service, friend. I know this is taking a hell of a toll on you, please please take care of yourself out here. We need you now more than ever, but we need you well and fit for what’s to come. Martin responded: What lovely words - thanks Jack. Yes Iaposm feeling the pressure, but thataposs trivial compared to the trauma many are facing being unable to afford to live. Martinaposs loyal legion of followers praised the tips, but expressed their disbelief that they were necessary in one of the worldaposs largest economies.Jon Wilson said: Good tips but itaposs  in one of the worldaposs wealthiest economies  weaposre one step away from the Universal Credit journal suggesting claimants Google how Bear Grylls went about sleeping in a deer carcass to keep warm. Anyway, hope your Calornian holiday pad is cosy Mr Sunak.Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Energy billsMartin Lewis" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: nightmare rubbish mountain attracts rats
story: Nightmare rubbish mountain that attracts rats and stinks is visible from Google EarthLocals and ward councillors got good news when Walsall Council served an enforcement notice to the land owners on February , but they have appealed it saying they need more timeA massive mountain of rubbish - which is visible from Google Earth - is leaving residents fed up Image: Google EarthByRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Apr |comments A nightmare mountain of rubbish which attracts rats and lets off an awful stink is so massive it can be seen on Google Earth.The terrible sight and awful stench comes from the Arrow Industrial Estate in Willenhall, where an enormous pile of trash has been building for several years.Among the rat-infested heap are pieces of metal, furniture, childrenaposs toys and general waste, Birmingham Live reports.Residents of the parallel street say theyaposre fed up of having to see the eyesore every day. Good news came at the end of February when Walsall Council served the landowners with an enforcement notice - requiring the site be cleared by the end of May. But the owners have appealed the notice, saying they need more time to clear their rubbish pile. Resident Michael Aston said: Iaposm over here very often feeding the ducks so to see that is terrible.  I feel for the people who live right next to it who open their windows and have to see that first thing in the morning. In the summer, you get a bit of a smell off it as well. It is ridiculous. We all know each other in this street but to have to deal with that on a daily basis is totally undesirable. If people want to walk along the canal or sell their house on this street, theyaposve got that to deal with. Having someoneaposs rubbish dumped on your doorstep. You see the odd rat going across there. Itaposs been there quite a while and is part of the view now but weaposre fed up of it. Another resident Wayne Phillips added: Itaposs been an absolute nightmare. Itaposs been there a couple of years and itaposs got worse and worse. Nothingaposs been done.  Now, what we are looking at is the summer is coming, spring is coming so we will get rats again, the smell will come back like it was before. There are a lot of kids on this street as well so to have to wake up to that every morning is unacceptable. Someone needs to take a bit of ownership really. Councillors in the area praised residents for their patience and support and added that despite the appeal potentially delaying the clean-up, they were pleased to see action being taken. Councillor Sarah-Jane Cooper said: We have been working on this issue for some time but we are very pleased to see that enforcement action is finally being taken against the occupiers of this site. The conditions nearby residents were forced to live with were completely unacceptable. Councillor Josh Whitehouse added: It’s great that action is finally being taken on Straight Road, the legalities of this case have delayed action and residents have been extremely patient in waiting to get to this point. We are very glad of the end result.” Local Conservative campaigner Amandeep Garcha also said: I’m sure everyone will be pleased to see this enforcement action being taken following our campaign to clear the site. The nearby residents have been extremely patient and have had to endure this for quite some time. We can’t wait to see this blight on the area gone from our town. news uk-news queen-uses-clever-two-word-"Queens savage response as photographer asks to remove crownByEmma RosemurgeyAudience Writer:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |comments Later this month the Queen will celebrate her Platinum Jubilee, marking  years since she took the the throne.During the seven decades of her reign, the Queen has met hundreds of thousands of people, often shaking their hand and making polite small talk. Given the huge number of people she meets, it would be fair to assume sheaposd have a hard time remembering who sheaposs actually meeting - and youaposd be right. But, ever the professional, the Queen has a clever strategy to make sure she appears as though sheaposs done her research every time she meets someone new.  Childrenaposs author Julia Donaldson - who penned the famous The Gruffalo book - experienced this first hand, when she was appointed CBE at the Queenaposs honours.Julia explained to Whimn : I was told the Queen goes through the potted biographies with a yellow marker and just two words get highlighted.So when you get called up, the equerry shows her the words. I did my little curtsey and she said, aposOh, so youaposre a writer. Youaposre very popular...apos I went off thinking aposwriter  popular...apos those must have been my two words.  The author went on to say she was full of admiration for Her Majesty, who does this with some  people every session and sheaposs on her feet the whole time. But, while absolutely no one can criticise the Queen for her dedication to her work, it turns out that there are some elements to her position that irritate her - no matter how well she manages to hide it.  Ever wondered what the Queen feels like when she enters a room filled with people, knowing theyaposre all nervous about meeting her  royal author Adam Heliker explained.Well, an RAF officer who served as an equerry discloses: aposOne summer day she asked me to join her on a walk at Balmoral. She talked about how irritating it was to go into a party and as she put it, watch people peel away, like the water parting as the bow of a ship ploughed through it. aposShe said she always felt it would be lovely to just slip into a party, wandering around incognito, talking to anyone she felt like. But the thing that most irritated her was the aposinevitable hushapos that always greeted her when they saw her walking in.Do you have a story to share  We want to hear all about it. news uk-news sainsburys-delivery-driver-sacked-after-"TikTok user says he was sacked by Sainsburys over videoByAlahna KindredNews Reporter:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |commentsA Sainsburyaposs delivery driver has claimed he was sacked for posting a video praising his job - all because he swore. Ollie Tutt, , posted the video saying how much he loved working as a delivery driver and described it as the easiest job in the country. The clip got more than a .million views on TikTok. The teen said: If you want an easy job, just go and work at Tesco, Sainsbury and do this delivering s**t. “It is possibly the easiest job Iaposve ever had, the best paying job Iaposve ever had and I get looked after. “I don’t do much, I just sit on the side of the road waiting to do these drops.“All the customers are f*****g lovely and haven’t had an occasion where they have been an a******e.” He went on and added: “Don’t work in the store though, that’s s**t and boring. “Seriouslyyou wanna do an easy job just do this.” Since it was shared on March , it has received more than , likes. However, a few days later Ollie, from East Sussex, shared another video saying his original one was seen by his manager and they werenapost happy.Ollie said: “That video got a lot more attention than I thought it would and caused a bit of a problem. “My manager told me that the store manager didn’t really mind but because I swore in that video it’s kind of bad for the company. “Which kind of is obvious because it doesn’t look really good on them.” Ollie says not long after his chat with management, he was sacked.  In a video shared on Sunday, he said: “Yep I got sacked and now I am worried about how I am going to pay my rent in a week. Ollie says he was sacked for gross misconduct and disrepute as well as for not caring enough about the whole situation. He added: “It’s not a big deal, like they are a multi-billion pound company and they care about a single video. “Yep you were all right about me losing my job, go f**k yourself. Now I am going to apply for new jobs.” A Sainsbury’s spokesperson said: “We are unable to discuss inidual colleague cases. “Any decision to review a colleague’s employment is not taken lightly and based on a range of factors.” Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON TescoSainsburysViral" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: schoolgirl 8 donates 500 easter
story: Schoolgirl, , donates  Easter eggs to childrens hospital in memory of brotherEllie Spackman, , has collected over  Easter eggs to donate to a Neo-natal unit and Childrens ward in memory of her baby brother, as she wants to help othersEllie Spackman has collected over  eggs to donate Image: Charlene Spackman   CATERS NEWSByZahna EklundAudience writerNiamh Kirk:,  Apr |comments A loving schoolgirl has collected over  Easter eggs that she plans to donate to the Neo-natal unit and the Childrenaposs ward at Gloucester Royal Hospital and the James Hopkins Trust in memory of her baby brother. Ellie Spackman, aged eight, visits the hospital and local charity every year with her parents Charlene and Ashley Spackman, both , and always donates chocolate eggs to children in need as a way to give back to the people who supported her family when her little brother Arthur was hospitalised.Arthur passed away in  at the age of two after being diagnosed with a very rare genetic terminal condition called Non-Ketotic Hyperglycinemia [NKH] when he was  days old. Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here. Gloucester Royal Hospital and the James Hopkins Trust - which provides respite for le-limited and threatened children - helped care for Arthur, and his big sister Ellie is now eager to do what she can to give back and show her appreciation for their hard work. Charlene explained: Since Arthuraposs death, Ellie has wanted to give back to the people who supported her when her brother was in their care. Ellie likes to help others like her brother and their siblings as she was helped when Arthur was in the hospital. We have been donating Easter eggs since . It started off with donating selection boxes at Christmas and thought we would do the same at Easter.  Ellie loves being involved, she will help us load up the car and help give them out to the hospital, she knows the nurses and they are familiar faces to Ellie. She is doing it in memory of her brother. It is so lovely to see the effect it has on children in the hospital. They are for the children who are in hospital, and siblings who are visiting, just like Ellie did. This year marks the familyaposs fourth time donating Easter eggs, and already have over  eggs stored in their house ready to donate to children when the time comes later this month. The Mirror is committed to more hopeful news. We recognise the news agenda can sometimes feel overwhelmingly negative.And while itaposs our job to keep you informed and hold those in power to account, we are making a commitment to also report more hopeful news. We will celebrate the people, places and movements that are bringing good into the world and, more than that, we will dig beneath the surface of important issues with the aim of finding hope.We will be firm in our convictions - but always fair-minded. By sharing solutions to problems, we can do more good and feel better about the world around us. Because we believe you deserve it. #mirrormorehopefulFollow on Twitter @mirrormorehope And follow Mirror More Hopeful on Facebook Charlene added: It is just our way of saying thank you. We do this to remember our little boy. A lot of local companies donate Easter eggs to us, and over the years it has grown, and now some local companies donate over  eggs to us. We already have over  eggs, and thataposs just whataposs in our house. We have stacked them all up in Arthuraposs room ready to be delivered next week before Easter Sunday.Do you have a story to sell  Get in touch with us at yourmirror@trinitymirror .Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON BabiesHospitalsEaster eggsMirror More Hopeful" data-immediate"data-immediate"Join the Secret Elves for celebration inspiration - and brilliant gt ideas and reviewsSpread the cheer!Invalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: uks worst covid hotspots revealed
story: UKs worst Covid hotspots revealed as hospitals full and rates higher than New figures released today suggest one in  people had the virus in the last three weeks of March - the highest since research started in May  - with Scotland and South West England recording the most infectionsThe Covid prevalence is thought to be at its highest since , figures released today show Image: NurPhoto via Getty ImagesByDave BurkeSenior News Reporter:,  Apr |comments UK Covid cases are at their highest recorded level since the start of the pandemic, a study shows - as NHS chiefs in the UKaposs worst hotspots warn hospitals are full.New figures suggest one in  people had the virus in the last three weeks of March - the highest since research started in May . But official Department of Health data shows the number of confirmed infections fell by nearly a third in a week - days after free lateral flow tests were scrapped across England. Latest data shows that the UKaposs worst-hit hotspots are in Scotland and the South West, with Na h-Eileanan Siar recording the highest infection rate. Plymouth has Englandaposs highest rate, while Swansea in Wales has the lowest in the UK. Latest maps show rates have plummeted in parts of the UK, with Wales in particular seeing a dramatic week-on-week drop. Todayaposs Department of Health figures show , people have tested positive for coronavirus in the past week - down a whopping , from the previous week.But the decision to abolish free lateral flow tests for all but a small number of eligible people in England means fewer are likely to be testing, experts say. Hospital admissions of people with Covid has gone up slightly, with , in seven days - but NHS bosses say the virus is only the cause of admission in around half of cases. Yesterday there were  people in ventilation beds - the highest number since mid-February. Tragically , people have died within  days of testing positive for Covid, the Department of Health figures show.  The  areas with the highest Covid rates areNa h-Eileanan Siar - ,. cases per , people South Ayrshire - ,. cases per , people Shetland Islands - , cases per , people North Ayrshire - ,. cases per , people Inverclyde - ,. cases per , people Plymouth - , cases per , people East Ayrshire - ,. cases per , people Falkirk - ,. cases per , people North Devon - ,. cases per , people East Lothian - ,. cases per , people Renfrewshire - ,. cases per , people Highland - ,. cases per , people Midlothian - , cases per , people Scottish Borders - ,. cases per , people Clackmannanshire - ,. cases per , people West Lothian - ,. cases per , people Torridge - ,. cases per , people Somerset West and Taunton - ,. cases per , people South Lanarkshire - ,. cases per , people Teignbridge - ,. cases per , peopleData published by Imperial College London and Ipsos MORI today suggests that one in  people across the England had the virus between March  and March . The prevalence rate shot up from . per cent in February to . per cent in March, the data shows. This is the highest rate since the study started in May , officials said today. It found that the seven places with the highest prevalence of cases were in the South West – Plymouth, Cornwall, South Hams, Torridge, Torbay, West Devon and Exeter. The other three highest – Braintree, Colchester and Maldon – were in the East of England.  Professor Paul Elliott, director of the REACT programme from Imperial’s School of Public Health, said: These trends are concerning since when a very high number of people are infected, this may lead to more people becoming seriously ill and needing to go to hospital. Although restrictions have ended, I would urge people to still behave cautiously to help protect others who might be vulnerable and avoid contact with other peopleyou have symptoms. This will help to slow the spread of the virus and lessen its impact on the NHS and our lives more broadly as we enter this next phase of the epidemic. The infection rate in each region is:Scotland - ,. South West -  South East - . East of England - . North East - . East Midlands - . West Midlands - . Yorkshire and The Humber - . North West - . London - . Northern Ireland - . Wales - . Today a chief medical officer in the South West called on families to accept loved ones home from hospital eventhey are Covid- positive as health services face a perfect storm.Dr Derek Sandeman, chief medical officer for Hampshire and Isle of Wight Integrated Care System, made his plea as he reported that almost every hospital in the two counties was full.  And the number of people with Covid- being cared for in hospitals across the area was  - more than . times higher than in early January.Dr Sandeman said: With staff sickness rates well above average, rising cases of Covid- and very high numbers of people needing treatment, we face a perfect storm - but there are some very specic ways in which people can help the frontline NHS and care teams. If you have a loved one who is in hospital, please help staff to help get them home quickly when they are well enough - eventhey are still testing positive for Covid.  That is enormously important to help us make beds available for those in greatest need. The high prevalence of cases has sparked calls for people to be careful. Dame Jenny Harries, Chief Executive of the UK Health Security Agency , said: These latest study results are another reminder that the pandemic is not over, and there is still a real risk to many of us catching Covid- with infection rates so high. That is why it is sensible to wear a mask in crowded, enclosed spaces, keep indoor spaces ventilated and stay away from othersyou have any symptoms of a respiratory illness, including Covid-. Vaccination continues to prevent a high number of cases resulting in severe disease, hospitalisation and death and remains the best way to protect us all. title: woman left crying vomiting after
story: Woman left crying and vomiting after absolutely horrendous -hour hospital stayThe woman, who does not want to be named, was taken to accident and emergency at Beaumont Hospital, Dublin by her GP with a letter saying she needed to be seen urgentlyBeaumont Hospital, Dublin Image: PAByEmma NevinGraeme Murray:,  Apr |comments A woman claims she was left aposcrying and vomitingapos after aposabsolutely horrendousapos -hour hospital stay. The woman, who does not want to be named, was taken to accident and emergency at Beaumont Hospital, Dublin by her GP, reports the Irish Mirror.He gave her a letter asking for her to seen urgently because she was suffering from extreme pain in her head and neck. She said: I was vomiting constantly and on the verge of passing out every time I stood up. I also had a rising temperature. The pain in my head was absolutely unbearable and in that moment I honestly would have rather died than be in the pain I was in.  My GP stated all this on the letter and said I urgently needed a CT scan. The patient arrived at AE at exactly :pm and was checked in by pm after presenting her letter to reception. The patient said she was triaged by a nurse at around :pm and was told she would have a few hours wait to see a doctor but not too long. The woman then described the absolutely horrendous  hour wait she endured before seeing a doctor. The nurse could see the pain I was in so she gave me two Paracetamol, she said. I have waited in Beaumont AE many times before so I knew I would have a bit of a wait ahead of me and that was okay. Nothing could have prepared me for the  hour wait I then had for a doctor.  hours I was left sitting in a plastic chair in extreme pain. It was absolutely horrendous. I cried and vomited my way through. I went up and down asking for painkillers and anti nausea tablets. The woman said that, at about am, she told a staff member that she couldnapost take the pain or the waiting any more and was told in response youaposve got  hours left, sit down, nothing I can do. The healthcare assistant in homecare said her heart absolutely broke seeing elderly people waiting in pain in the emergency department. She said: At one point, a man in his ’s who was with his daughter, ended up leaving the department at around am. He was in too much pain to continue waiting. Everyone around me was in the exact same boat. I was probably one of the youngest waiting and I knowit was one of my parents sitting in that AE department I’d be absolutely furious. For the  hours I was sitting there, I got  minutes sleep and that was on the floor. The patient said she was brought in to get her bloods done at around am and continued to wait for hours afterwards to see a doctor. She said: The next afternoon while I was still waiting, at about pm, a member of staff came out to apologise on behalf of Beaumont Hospital for the long waiting times. She said the people who presented to AE the day before at pm were now only being seen by a doctor. She said thatyou were waiting and you think your illness could be dealt with by a GP then you should go home. Another staff member then proceeded to tell everyone they should only staythey’re aposreally sickapos. The woman said that one staff member asked hershe was okay and when the woman said aposno to be honest I’ve been waiting all nightapos the staff member said aposwell, ambulances are priorityapos and the woman burst out crying. After waiting all night, I needed a bit of empathy, not to be made feel the way that comment made me feel. I’m a very understanding person and of course I understand ambulances and those who are extremely unwell are a priority but I’m also a human being who’s in pain and who’s been left sitting evening, night and morning on a plastic chair. The patient said she was called by a doctor at pm and was seated in another area.She said an elderly woman on a trolley looked over at her and said: “I’ve been here since amand I haven’t seen a doctor yet, isn’t it like a war zone The patient said her CT scan was done quite quickly and her doctor told her to wait back in the chair beside the nurses station where I had been seated. She claims other staff members told her to move and she had to go back out to the waiting room where her doctor eventually found her at pm. She apologised for the wait and also said she hadn’t realised I’d been moved out. My doctor was absolutely lovely and made me feel heard and understood. The patient said the awful experience has put her off ever wanting to go back into Beaumont.She said: I understand hospitals are under pressure due to Covid and staff shortages but it is absolutely inhumane to leave someone sitting on a plastic chair for  hours especially with so much pain.The Mirror has contacted Beaumont Hospital for comment. title: woman who agreed pole dance
story: Woman who agreed to pole dance for ex-boyfriend murdered and had body set alightLouise Rumps body was found at the foot of her bed by firefighters who had been called out by neighbours when they saw smoke coming from her flat in the village of Kensworth, BedfordshireLouise Rump was killed at her home in Plewes Close, Kensworth, Bedfordshire Image: South Beds News ServiceByLucy SkouldingFreelance writer:,  Apr |comments A woman who agreed to pole dance for her former boyfriend was murdered and had her body set alight, a jury was told today.The body of Louise Rump, , was found at the foot of her bed by fire-fighters who had been called out by neighbours when they saw smoke coming from her flat in the village of Kensworth, Bedfordshire“She had been killed and set on fire,” said David Matthew, prosecuting at St Albans crown court.Mr Matthew said her ex-partner Habib Jackson, , had made a “deal” with Louise. He said: “She was going to dance for him in underwear he selected. That deal went badly wrong. The fire brigade found her dead. She had been killed by asphyxia. Jackson of Dunstable Road, Toddington, Beds and his business partner and fellow security guard Christopher Hayward, also , of Fensome Drive, Houghton Regis, Beds both deny murder.  The jury was told by Judge Michael Kay QC that Jackson refused to leave prison and would be tried in his absence. Hayward is aided in court by an intermediary. Opening the case, Mr Matthew said: “Louise Rump was killed on Friday th October . She was  at the time. She was killed in her flat in Plewes Close, Kensworth.” He said she had been alive and well earlier in the day when neighbours had seen her and she had exchanged WhatApp messages with a cousin until . in the morning. “Sometime between a quarter past eleven and half past midday she was killed, he said. “Both of these defendants, in that one hour  minutes, were at her address. She was found dead after they left.“The pathologist found she had been killed by asphyxia before her body was set on fire. There was signs of an attack with bruising on her face, her left hand, wrist and pelvis. The fire was a quite deliberate attempt to destroy the traces her attacker might have left,” he said. Telephone, Automatic Number Plate Recognition and CCTV evidence from Kensworth Village Stores were alleged to have tracked the two men’s cars as they drove from Toddington to Kensworth on the morning of the killing. At . in the afternoon, CCTV from the shop recorded the two cars leaving the village, the court heard. Jackson was seen to stop by the side of the road and dumped a jumper that had Louise’s blood on it and a cardboard box, the jury was told. When the fire fighters entered the flat they found a pole dancer’s pole in the lounge and Louise’s body in the bedroom. Mr Matthew said: “That was where the fire was lit. The curtains had caught fire and there was smoke damage. At the end of the bed was a plastic water bottle. There is reason to think there had been petrol or some accelerant in it to get the fire going. The jury was told Jackson referred to himself as Louise’s ‘Sugar Daddy’ at times. They had been involved in a relationship that had ended about a year earlier. In a message on  October Jackson wrote to Louise: “It has been a year baby, since I was deep where I belong.”He went on: “Can’t you give me what I crave ” She replied: “No.” Mr Matthew said, referring to the planned pole dance, Jackson wrote: “G-string and undies ready ” When Jackson was questioned by the police the day after the killing he said they had an on-off relationship, the court heard. He denied he had been to the flat on the day of the killing but said he had been there on Thursday th February when they had a play fight and she had scratched his face. The prosecutor said there was a scratch on Jackson’s face under his right eye. Hayward made no comment to answer police questions. The case continues.Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON CCTVMurderCCTV footageCourt caseCrown courtCrime" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news us-news non-verbal-teen-lost-woods-"Teenager found after getting lost in woods by hitting rocksByHetty ChangTim FitzsimonsSamantha Mordi:,  Apr |commentsA non-verbal teenageraposs affinity for rocks has proved to be le-saving after the sound of him banging them together alerted a rescue team to his location. The teen ran into nearby trees and went missing after going on a hike with mother and sister in Los Angeles, Calornia. Members of the search and rescue team said they heard a piercing sound through the thick bushes of the Crescenta Valley Park, where they were searching for the developmentally-delayed teen.After hearing the sound repeatedly, Sherf Steve Goldsworthy said he he had a hunch to follow the unusual clinking noise through. as reported by NBC news. Sherf Goldsworthy, a member of the Los Angeles County Sherfaposs Department Montrose Search-and-Rescue Team said: We were hollering down in this canyon, and I heard something come back. It sounded like somebody taking two rocks and putting them together. I could hear the rocks hit, and a slight echo. I could hear that three dferent times.In a post on Facebook discussing the incident, the team wrote: Our team member went down the mountainside and made contact with the missing person. Recognizing the sensitivity of the situation, he worked to build a rapport with the teenager. After gaining the trust of the missing person, he led him up the mountain to safety. Once at the top, he was treated by paramedics and released to his family. The team found the -year-old north of the park with the help of aerial footage. He adds: I found him basically sitting under an oak tree, probably three miles from where he was last seen with his mum. “He will go out of his way to kick a rock, pick up a rock, throw a rock, Those were, like, his favorite things, so I picked up the rock and threw it down the gully, and he looked at me, and he ended up giving me a fist bump. title: pet owner splashes out nearly
story: Pet owner splashes out nearly £, to clone her cat after she diedKelly Anderson, , from Texas, has told how her cat Chai, who died in , was the "closest thing she had to a soulmate" and she decided to have her cloned costing her almost £,Kelly Anderson told how she had her cat cloned Image: ITVByTim HanlonNews Reporter:,  Apr |commentsA cat owner has told how she has spent almost £, on cloning her “soulmate” pet as she was so upset when she died.Kelly Anderson, , from Texas, was mourning the loss of her five-year-old cat Chai, who died in , when she decided to get in touch with a company that offers animal cloning services.She said that the process of having her cat cloned took four years and now she has a new pet called Belle who shares the same DNA.Speaking on ITV ’s This Morning, Kelly said that Chai was the “closest thing she could describe to a soulmate.”She said: “I lost her very young, so when she passed I remembered a conversation I had with my roommate about cloning and I reached out to ViaGen Pets.  “Belle came into my le just last year.” Texas based ViaGen Pets is part of TransOva Genetics that has been cloning horses and livestock for  years and recently they have also started to offer the service for dogs and cats. Kelly had her cat cloned for ,and it is now , more expensive while the cost of cloning dogs is ,.  She explained: “She is her own cat. I never expected her to be Chai, I never wanted her to be Chai. It is a piece of Chai and that is what matters most to me, that I get to carry on a piece of her.” The decision to clone animals is controversial and many people on social media questioned why she didn’t adopt a cat. One person tweeted that “animals are not objects”.  Another said: “It’s not the same pet you had. It won’t have the same personality or even develop the same connections to you. If you’re trying to get over a pet’s death, cloning is the exact opposite thing you should be doing.”Others on Kellyaposs Instagram complimented her on her cloned cat.One said: So adorable, while another added: Handsome. And Kelly has also said that she does adopt cats and has homed over  in the past and justied the cost saying that people spend the same amount on cars regularly. title: adorable puppy becomes best friends
story: Adorable puppy becomes best friends with rescue kittens and sleeps beside them at nightOne-year-old puppy Popsy didnt want to say goodbye to fostered rescue kittens, Fawn, Hera and Ralph, after the four of them shared each other food bowls, beds and toysIt was an unusual but inseparable bond Image: Catherine Walsh   SWNSByNia DaltonSpecialist WriterAmy Reast:,  Apr |comments This adorable friendship between a puppy and a trio of rescue kittens proves that people neednapost fight aposlike cat and dogapos.One-year-old pup Popsy has always got on with cats and kittens, but this bond was like no other.Owner Catherine Walsh, , from Wapping, London, regularly fosters for the animal charity Battersea, and has taken in several sets over the years.But when she took rescue kitties, Fawn, Hera and Ralph, into her home on March , she was shocked by their reception. The four friends instantly became inseparable and did everything together, from playing to eating and sleeping. to our TeamDogs newsletter for your weekly dose of dog news, pictures and stories. The cute pictures show just some of the precious moments the unusual gang shared together before the kittens eventually had toto the rescue shelter last week. Catherine said: Popsy has grown up with a few sets of kittens, so she is used to them. As soon as Fawn, Hera and Ralph came in, they were like best friends. They would all sleep together in the same basket, play together with each otheraposs toys, and even eat each otheraposs food. Sometimes the kittens would try and each Popsyaposs food, and she seemed to prefer their food too. Anything Popsy would do, they would want to do as well - they would wait at the door for us to get back when I took her on a walk. The kittens just totally fell in love with Popsy, and she fell in love with them too! Popsy isnapost the only dog to have formed an unlikely friendship this week - Ted the farm dog has stepped in to help feed orphaned lambs.The black Labrador jumped at the opportunity to balance the bottle of milk between his teeth, while six-week-old lamb Frank suckled. Farmer Libbie Harris, , from Bristol, decided to teach Ted how to muck in after she was struggling to juggle all of the animals - and he couldnapost be a cuter helping hand. Libbie said: He was able to hold the bottle straight away butit’s full its a bit too heavy. Now I give him the bottle to hold when it’s half empty then I can feed the other two at the same time.Do you have a dog story to tell  Contact nia.dalton@reachplc.Read MoreRead More Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON TeamDogsDogsAnimalsCats" data-immediate"data-immediate"Calling all dog lovers!to TeamDogs for your weekly dose of dog news, pictures and stories.Invalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: pregnant woman fumes man refuses
story: Pregnant woman fumes as man refuses to give up a seat hes using to rest his handA woman took to Reddit to ask whether she was in the wrong for how she reacted when a man on the bus refused to give up the seat next to him to she could sit down Image: Getty Images WestendByPaige HollandShowbiz Audience Writer:,  Apr |commentsA tired pregnant woman has been slammed by her husband for the inappropriate way she dealt with a man who refused to give up a seat on the bus.In a post on Reddit, the woman, who is eight months pregnant, explained that she takes public transport to work daily, most often the bus.Often, due to the times that she travels, the bus is busy, but sheaposs lucky enough that decent folk volunteer their seat for her. On one occasion, she gets on the bus and for once, spots an empty seat. I go to sit but I find a guy in his business attire sitting there with his hand on the empty seat . I say excuse me and ask him to remove his hand so I could sit, but he tells me the seat was apostaken.apos When she asks by who, he says his hand. For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here.She struggles to stle a laugh, and tells him that sheaposs tired and please could he move it so she could sit down - but he refuses and tells her my pregnancy isnapost his problem.I had enough at this point, my legs were burning and my back was hurting, so I go ahead and sit on his hand. The man then freaked out and tried to quickly remove his hand, while shouting at her about how disrespectful sheaposd been. I argue back but then he gets off after saying I was being inappropriate and disrespectful, she said. Everyone stares at me and I just sit there feeling a bit of shame about what happened.When she got home, she recalled what had happened to her husband, who told her that I did indeed act inappropriately and shouldnapost have made this guy uncomfortable by sitting on his hand like that. He tells me I f**ked up and this was totally inappropriate despite me saying I was so tired of standing and was in desperate need to sit down, she concluded. Reddit users were quick to assure her she wasnapost in the wrong at all and many found it quite funny, as one person said: I canapost believe you stole the seat from his only lover!Another wrote: I’m having a terrible day and this made me laugh, thank you. A third put: I hope you farted, to which the woman replied saying: Oh God nooo that wouldaposve been a lot worse, but thataposs hilarious. I can only imagine his reaction, oh dear! And someone  wrote: Iaposm not pregnant and would do the same thing. Who the hell does he think he is denying someone  a seat they paid for Have you got a story to share We want to hear all about it. title: were beautiful go dates tinder
story: Were too beautul to go on dates - Tinder, Bumble and Hinge have rejected usAlaw Haff, , from Mold, Wales, makes £, a year on OnlyFans, but says she got kicked off dating apps because people dont think her pictures are real.Alaw is amongst the woman struggling to find a partner Image: Jam Press @alawpxByRosaleen FentonDeputy Features Editor:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |commentsA group of beautul women have revealed their struggles when it comes to landing a date. While you might think there arenapost any issues - these women say their stunning styles are actually holding them back when it comes to love. One woman says she was kicked off Bumble because the app believed she was a catfish while another says her dates are intimidated by her looks. REJECTED BY BUMBLE Playboy model Tahlia Paris, , from Los Angeles, Calornia, says her photos were removed from Bumble even though they didnapost break any guidelines – and she believes itaposs because she is too beautul.Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here  She has been single for four years and was hoping being on an app would help her find the one, but she was shocked when her photos were removed by the appaposs moderators. “I was on the app for not even a few hours because pictures I tried posting to my profile were removed even though they were normal photos,” Tahlia, who also works as a DJ, said. “It happened three or four times to dferent pictures and Bumble only allowed one of my pictures to stay up, which was really hurting my odds in the dating app world. “The photos I posted very were basic. One was a selfie of myself, one was a picture a friend of mine had taken at the beach. “I tried to keep it very PG and not model-esque at all. I wanted guys to not stop at my profile because I’m a professional model but because I was just another average girl looking to date. MY LOOKS INTIMATE DATESElizabeth Marie Chevalier, , from San Diego, Calornia, has over . million Instagram followers, but feels her looks are too intimidating for potential partners. The Maxim and Playboy model has been single for six months and says even when she does get a date, it usually doesnapost do well as men struggle to speak to her. Dating is hard — guys are scared because Iaposm so beautul, Elizabeth said. Iaposve been told that Iaposm intimidating to guys because Iaposm tall – Iaposm ft  – and Iaposm beautul and I have a very intense personality. The men that do chat me up are usually too cocky and self-obsessed, they clearly go for every pretty girl in the room,apos she said. aposThey see us as trophies. I know I wear a bikini online but itaposs a job, most guys canapost see past that. KICKED OFF TINDER  Alaw Haff, , from Mold, Wales, makes £, a year on OnlyFans, but says she got kicked off dating apps because people donapost think her pictures are real. She claims she has been blocked from using three apps so far – Tinder, Bumble and Hinge. Alaw claims she was first banned from Tinder in September  and again in December  after getting her account back. She was also allegedly booted from Hinge in March  and claims to have been kicked off Bumble in . “I had problems with a couple of my pictures so I’d just replace them with others, she said “I would never post anything offensive but it’s hard to find a picture of myself wearing clothes when % of my pictures are in lingerie or swimwear due to my work. SO HOT MY PICS WERE USED TO CATFISH OnlyFans model Luna Benna, , who now lives in Florida, says her pics were so attractive, she got banned from Tinder because the images kept being used to catfish people. She first signed up in  and even went on some dates but was shocked when her account was removed. People were stealing my photos and making money using my images. Catfishing, basically, she complained. It’s really disappointing when people create fake profiles after stealing my images – it’s sad for the person behind the image, and sad for the person who gets catfished. There’s so many fake profiles out there, whenever I start a legit account I get reported and Tinder has me taken down! I’ve had a lot of dferent looks over the years, and have been on the Internet forever, so they have lots of options to work with.There’s even a fake Facebook of me somewhere that someone made, it currently has thousands of followers!I just need to keep reminding myself I can’t do anything about it, and it’s out of my control. story: British man, , and boy, , missing after ers vanish  miles off Malaysian islandThe -year-old man and -year-old boy were taking part in a ing training exercise off Pulau Tokong Sanggol, near the coastal town of Mersing in the country’s southeast, on Wednesday afternoon has launched a search and rescue operation." content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _MALAYSIA-SEASIA-MIGRANTS.jpg" width"" "" Malaysia’s Maritime Enforcement Agencyhas launched a search and rescue operation Image: AFP via Getty ImagesByAbigail OLearyNews Reporter:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |commentsA British man and teenager are among four ers missing nine miles off the coast of a Malaysian island. The -year-old man and -year-old boy were taking part in a ing training exercise off Pulau Tokong Sanggol, near the coastal town of Mersing in the country’s southeast, on Wednesday afternoon. They have been reported missing along with an -year-old woman from France and a -year-old Norwegian woman. Malaysia’s Maritime Enforcement Agencyhas launched a search and rescue operation. Coastguard teams, the police and the fisheries department set out at around .pm local time . The ing team were said to have been ferried to a location before being reported missing by a skipper, who reported the incident to the emergency services when the group didnapost emerge to the surface.  Johor Malaysian Maritime Enforcement Agencydirector First Admiral Nurul Hizam Zakaria said: The tekongof a boat that ferried the four foreigners to the spot made a report about the ers not surfacing after holding a ing exercise at around noon. “The missing four are two British men and two women, a French and a Norwegian, between the ages of  and .  A forward operating base has been set up at the Mersing District Council public jetty. Pulau Tokong Sanggol, the island from which the group went missing, is around nine nautical milesfrom Tanjung Leman, Mersing. The area is popular with foreign and domestic tourists due to its resorts dotted along the coast and nearby islands, loved for ing. title: brit sniper found children tied
story: Brit sniper found children tied up and shot through head in Russian war crime horrorShane Matthew was on the frontline in war-torn Ukraine for around a month and describes his experiences as he witnessed the full horror of the Russian invasionShane Matthew, pictured on tour in Iraq in , was in Ukraine for around a month Image: Solent News  Photo AgencyByConnor GormleyChris DyerLucy Skoulding:,  Apr |comments An ex-British Army sniper saw first-hand the aposatrocitiesapos committed by Russian forces who occupied Ukrainian territory near Kyiv.Shane Matthew, , was in the war-torn country for around a month on Ukraineaposs frontline witnessing the horrors of the Russian invasion. The former British Army sniper has seen a lot of fighting since his arrival in the battle-ravaged country, as part of the Foreign Legion of Territorial Defense of Ukraine.The group was formed by President Volodomyr Zelenskyy, who urged foreigners to come to Ukraine to help repel Vladimir Putinaposs war machine. A fully qualied field medic, Mr Matthew started out in the Princess of Wales Royal Regiment based in Portsmouth before leaving to try his hand at private military contracting. Want all the latest news and analysis from Ukraine to our World News Bulletin here  He has combat experience in Iraq, Afghanistan and Syria, but described Ukraine as one of the most horrendous experiences of my le. Mr Matthew, who works on Crimsham Farm in Bognor Regis, West Sussex, left his Chichester home last month to help Ukrainian nationals defend their home from Russian invaders. He snuck back home on Saturday night, having trained more than , Ukrainian volunteers in basic first aid and fundamental soldiering. Although impressed by the fighting grit of the Ukrainian people and optimistic about their chances against the Russians, Mr Matthew was horried by what he saw.  He said: We were stuck outside Bucha and I was fighting for four days. When we managed to get control of the city, we discovered whataposs being broadcast on the news at the moment. Streets littered with dead bodies. Children with their hands bound and their heads shot. Itaposs beyond atrocious. Determined to document the hardship, Mr Matthew plans toto Ukraine in a few weeks time, taking a camera with him to get the truth out to as many people as possible. He added: I want to photograph whataposs happened and get it out in the public that war crimes have been committed. I want people to see exactly whataposs been going on.  Mr Matthew flew to Poland at the start of last month, before crossing the border and meeting a Ukrainian colonel, who agreed to arm him and  other volunteer fighters. From there the experienced sniper travelled to Ukraineaposs under-siege capital, transporting some kg of medical supplies that had been donated to him. The former military contractor hit the frontline, helping treat wounded Ukrainians and providing training for civilians rising up against Putinaposs forces.Since Russia forces retreated from Buch and Irpin, just outside Kyiv, harrowing images of the devastation caused by the occupation have emerged.Civilians shot dead with their hands tied behind their backs and mass graves were uncovered, along with allegations of women being raped and killed in front of their children. President Zelensky told the UN Security Council yesterdaythere was not a single crime that Russian troops had not committed in Bucha. The International Criminal Courtlaunched an investigation into the claims of war crimes and could issue arrest warrants to bring the perpetrators to trial in The Hague. title: putin wants build pro russia
story: Vladimir Putin wants to build pro-Russia empire from Vlaostok to PortugalWorld leaders are calling for President Vladimir Putin to be tried for war crimes but experts are concerned these horrors could continue as the despot pushes forward with a grander plan to build a sprawling empireDmitry Medvedev said Putin launched his brutal invasion of the former Soviet republic to bring peace to Ukraine, in a Telegram post Image: VIA REUTERSByKaisha LangtonAssistant News Editor:,  Apr Updated:,  Apr |comments Russian President Vladimir Putin is endeavouring to build a pro-Russian empire stretching from Vlaostok to Lisbon, a former Russian president has warned. Ex-president and deputy chairman of the Russian Security Council Dmitry Medvedev said Putin launched his brutal invasion of the former Soviet republic to bring peace to Ukraine, in a Telegram post.The shocking allegations were made as Western leaders shared fears Moscow is planning a new military offensive in southern and eastern parts of Ukraine. Medvedev said: To change the bloody and full of  myths consciousness of a part of today’s Ukrainians is the most important goal. The goal is for the sake of the peace of future generations of Ukrainians themselves and the opportunity to finally build an open Eurasia – from Lisbon to Vlaostok.  He further accused Nazis, murderers and collaborators of stirring up Russophobia in Ukraine since the collapse of the Soviet Union in . The ex-Russian leader also said Putinaposs special military operation in Ukraine was undertaken in a bid to demilitarise and de-Nazy the country. Medvedev added the offensive will not only be decided on the battlefields. He also questioned the legitimacy of Ukrainian sovereignty saying: The passionate part of Ukrainians has been praying for the Third Reich for the last  years.  The former president revealed on Wednesday Moscow intends to fight attempts to seize Russian property abroad in courts around the globe. He said: Our opponents … should understand that they will face a large number of cases in courts. Both in the national courts of the United States and Europe and in international courts. Medvedevaposs comments come amid heightened concerns from Western officials including NATO chief Jens Stoltenberg that Rusasia will push to try to capture Ukraineaposs eastern region of Donbas in coming weeks.Officials warned Russian troops may attempt to create a land bridge to occupied Crimea.Ukrainian President Volodymr Zelensky yesterday accused Russian military of carrying out the worst crimes since World War II. He told the UN Security Council civilians had been murdered and Russian tanks had crushed people for pleasure. After finishing his speech via video link, he showed gruesome images of dead Ukrainians including charred and mutilated bodies. Mr Zelensky said: The Russian military searched for and purposefully killed anyone who served our country They killed entire families, adults and children, and they tried to burn the bodies.  He urged the UN to take action saying failure to do so would make the world body ineffectual. Mr Zelensky added: Are you ready to close the UN  And the time of international law is gone  If your answer is no, then you need to act immediately. President Zelensky was praised for his ferocious and passionate attack on Russian military, telling the UN that accountability must be inevitable. He said: We are dealing with a state that turns its veto at the UN Security Council into the right to [cause] death. Before Putin launched his invasion into Ukraine, the Russian parliamentaposs deputy chairman Pyotr Tolstoy said Finland and Ukraine should be incorporated back into an enlarged Russia.Speaking in January, he claimed NATO members Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania will “crawl” back under the Kremlin’s sway after realising the “insignicance of their position”, according to Znak media. Tolstoy did not specy how this “restoration” might happen, but claimed it could be in the next ten years. He later claimed his comments about the Kremlin restoring its old empire at a Russian Press Day event had been a “joke”, but he previously made clear he holds such views. Last year he declared “there will be no Ukraine”, describing it as “part of Russia which has temporarily seceded”.
